summary: Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) is a rare, aggressive type of skin cancer that begins in the Merkel cells, which are found in the epidermis of the skin. It often appears as a firm, painless, flesh-colored or bluish-red nodule, most commonly on sun-exposed areas of the body.
risk_factors: Weakened immune system (e.g., due to HIV, organ transplant, or certain medications)
History of other skin cancers (basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, melanoma)
symptoms: Firm, painless, flesh-colored or bluish-red nodules
Most commonly on sun-exposed areas (face, head, neck, arms)
diagnosis: Imaging tests (CT scan, PET scan, MRI) to check for spread
